revision.text:
'''Patrick Reinsborough''' (born 1972) is an American writer, activist, social change theorist and practitioner. He is the co-author of ''Re:Imagining Change: How to Use Story-based Strategy to Win Campaigns, Build Movements and Change the World'' ([[PM Press]] 2010/2017) and contributor to social movement anthologies including ''Globalize Liberation: How to Uproot the System and Build a Better World'' ([[City Lights Bookstore|City Lights]] 2004) and ''Beautiful Trouble: a toolbox for revolution'' ([[OR Books]] 2012).
== Narrative Strategy == Reinsborough's writing and political work deals with building transformative movements, shifting cultural narratives and political imagination<ref>{{Cite book|title=Zapatismo Beyond Borders: New Imaginations of Political Possibility|last=Knasnabish|first=Alex|publisher=University of Toronto Press|year=2008|isbn=978-0-8020-9633-3|location=Toronto|pages=172–173}}</ref> with a focus on the ecological crisis.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Reinsborough|first=Patrick|date=November 2010|title=Giant Whispers: Narrative Power, Radical Imagination and a Future Worth Fighting For...|url=https://ojs.library.queensu.ca/index.php/affinities/article/view/6140|journal=Affinities: A Journal of Radical Theory, Culture, and Action|volume=4|pages=|via=RefWorks}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.democracynow.org/2002/2/7/redefining_globalization_to_mean_global_justice|title=Redefining Globalization to Mean Global Justice for the Environment and the World|last=Goodman|first=Amy|date=February 7, 2002|work=Democracy Now!|access-date=September 21, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> He authored the widely circulated essay/zine "Decolonizing the Revolutionary Imagination".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.joaap.org/1/de_colonizing/index.html|title=The Journal of Aesthetics & Protest|website=www.joaap.org|access-date=2018-04-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rachel.org/?q=en/node/3665|title=Decolonizing the Revolutionary Imagination... {{!}} Environmental Research Foundation|website=www.rachel.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/51060187|title=Globalize liberation : how to uproot the system and build a better world|last=|first=|date=2004|publisher=City Lights Books|others=Solnit, David.|year=|isbn=0872864200|location=San Francisco, CA|pages=161–212|oclc=51060187}}</ref> He was a founding member of the ''smart''Meme Strategy & Training Project,<ref>Center for Media and Democracy, Sourcewatch
http://www.sourcewatch.org/index.php/Patrick_Reinsborough </ref> which began in 2002 training grassroots activists to apply [[meme]] theory<ref>{{Cite book|title=Getting Past Capitalism: History, Vision, Hope|last=Kaufman|first=Cynthia|publisher=Lexington Books|year=2014|isbn=978-0-7391-9065-4|location=Plymouth UK|pages=131}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Breaking the Spell: A History of Anarchist Filmmakers, Videotape Guerrillas and Digital Ninjas|last=Robé|first=Chris|publisher=PM Press|year=2017|isbn=978-1-62963-233-9|location=Oakland|pages=19}}</ref> as a way to shift political debates, amplify social change efforts and "change the story".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wagingnonviolence.org/2011/02/smartmeme-pioneers-social-change-storytelling/|title=SmartMeme pioneers social change storytelling|last=Farrell|first=Bryan|date=February 21, 2011|website=Waging Nonviolence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 13, 2017}}</ref> Reinsborough is one of the creators of story-based strategy methodology<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.insidestoriesonline.com/2010_12_01_archive.html|title=Inside Stories Podcast 27: Patrick Reinsborough of smartMeme|last=VanDeCarr|first=Paul|date=December 30, 2010|website=Inside Stories|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 20, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=C SS|title=Story-based Strategy Breaks Glass Ceiling|date=2013-05-02|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vy0e5h1eWaM&t=4s|accessdate=2018-04-06}}</ref> and associated with widely used social change frameworks such as "narrative power analysis",<ref>{{Cite book|title=Beautiful Trouble: a toolbox for revolution|last=Boyd|first=Andrew|publisher=OR Books|year=2012|isbn=978-1-935928-57-7|location=New York|pages=244–246}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Erler|first=Carolyn|date=Spring 2009|title=Memory and Erasure: Applying Visual Narrative Power Analysis to the Image War Between Dow Chemical Corporation and the International Campaign for Justice in Bhopal|url=https://search.proquest.com/openview/be0c3f5496b42713c678f9992866031d/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=40077|journal=Journal of Cultural Research in Art Education|volume=27|pages=42–62|via=ProQuest}}</ref> "points of intervention"<ref>{{Cite book|title=Beautiful Trouble: a toolbox for revolution|last=Boyd|first=Andrew|publisher=OR Books|year=2012|isbn=978-1-935928-57-7|location=New York|pages=250–252}}</ref> and the "battle of the story".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://orionmagazine.org/article/our-storied-future/|title=Our Storied Future|last=Solnit|first=Rebecca|date=January 16, 2008|website=Orion Magazine|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 18, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Breaking the Spell: A History of Anarchist Filmmakers, Videotape Guerrillas and Digital Ninjas|last=Robé|first=Chris|publisher=PM Press|year=2017|isbn=978-1-62963-233-9|location=Oakland|pages=280–281}}</ref> He co-founded and was the Executive Director of the Center for Story-based Strategy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://keywiki.org/Center_for_Story-based_Strategy|title=Center for Story-based Strategy - KeyWiki|website=keywiki.org|language=en|access-date=2018-02-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://stproject.org/from-the-field/tools-action-center-story-based-strategy/|title=Tools in Action: Center for Story-Based Strategy {{!}} Social Transformation Project|website=stproject.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-05}}</ref>
== Global Justice Activism == Reinsborough was a prominent organizer, trainer and media spokesperson for the U.S. wing of the anti-corporate globalization movement often known as the [[global justice movement]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?156615-1/imf-world-bank-protests-wrap|title=IMF World Bank Protests Wrap, Apr 17 2000 {{!}} Video {{!}} C-SPAN.org|website=C-SPAN.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-05}}</ref> and was involved in mass actions such as the [[1999 Seattle WTO protests|shutdown of the World Trade Organization in 1999]] actions against the [[World Bank]] and [[International Monetary Fund]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/2000/04/18/protests-end-with-voluntary-arrests/0d629058-fc77-4547-9033-e1aacbd3c5b9/|title=Protests End With Voluntary Arrests|last=Montgomery|first=David|date=2000-04-18|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-02-05|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?172394-1/imfworld-bank-meeting-protest|title=IMFWorld Bank Meeting Protest, Sep 3 2002 {{!}} Video {{!}} C-SPAN.org|website=C-SPAN.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-05}}</ref> the [[World Economic Forum]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.democracynow.org/2002/2/7/redefining_globalization_to_mean_global_justice|title=Redefining Globalization to Mean Global Justice for the Environment and the World|work=Democracy Now!|access-date=2018-02-05}}</ref> and the protests against the [[Free Trade Area of the Americas|Free Tree Area of the Americas]] Meeting in Miami in 2003.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.alternet.org/story/17293/information_warfare_in_miami|title=Information Warfare in Miami|last=Hogue|first=Ilyse|date=2003-11-30|work=AlterNet|access-date=2018-02-05|last2=Reinsborough|first2=Patrick}}</ref>
== Anti-War == He has been a public voice against U.S. militarism and called for the American public to engage in mass nonviolent disruption to stop wars.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/03/19/us/threats-responses-dissent-disagreements-about-civil-disobedience-divide-america.html|title=THREATS AND RESPONSES: DISSENT; Disagreements About Civil Disobedience Divide America's Antiwar Movement|last=Zernike|first=Kate|date=2003-03-19|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-02-05|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> He was an anti-war organizer and media strategist working with the San Francisco-based mobilization [[Direct Action to Stop the War]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://chicago.indymedia.org/archive/newswire/display/76316/index.php|title=Chicago Indymedia: From Piece Movement to Peace Movement: San Francisco Self-Organizes to Implode Empire|website=chicago.indymedia.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-06}}</ref> which led mass protests against the 2003 U.S. invasion of Iraq.<ref>{{Citation|last=Lafore|first=Beca|title=Shutdown: The Rise and Fall of Direct Action to Stop the War|date=2009-02-17|url=https://www.amazon.com/Shutdown-Rise-Fall-Direct-Action/dp/B001HVZOI4|publisher=Mvd Visual|language=English|accessdate=2018-02-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/politics/joegarofoli/article/Anti-war-activists-ready-a-response-2627756.php|title=Anti-war activists ready a response / Demonstrators told 'to be nimble' -- S.F. rally today|work=SFGate|access-date=2018-02-05}}</ref> He has also advocated for making connections between opposing war and other issues such as racial and economic justice, corporate power and the climate crisis.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.warresisters.org/win/win-springsummer-2008/listening-process-section-4-how-do-we-build-more-multiracial-and-cross|title=Listening Process (Section 4) - How do we build a more multiracial and cross-class antiwar movement?|date=2010-03-26|work=War Resisters League|access-date=2018-02-05|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dev.autonomedia.org/node/2297|title=Patrick Reinsborough, "Connecting the Imperial Dots" {{!}} InterActivist Info Exchange|website=dev.autonomedia.org|access-date=2018-02-05}}</ref>
== Environment and Climate == Reinsborough has been associated with a number of campaigns challenging the human rights and ecological impacts of fossil fuels as well as demanding stronger action to address climate change. He helped organize an international solidarity campaign supporting Colombia’s indigenous [[U'wa people|U’wa people]], who threatened to commit collective suicide to protest oil drilling on their ancestral territories.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nacla.org/article/colombias-uwa-people-real-price-oil|title=Colombia's U'Wa People: The Real Price of Oil|website=NACLA|language=en|access-date=2018-02-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/2002/04/20/an-unnatural-journey-for-natures-cause/109d93d6-2098-4132-8b74-2c089c5fc4f6/|title=An Unnatural Journey for Nature's Cause|last=Twomey|first=Steve|date=2002-04-20|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-02-05|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Globalize Liberation: How to Uproot the System and Build a Better World|last=Solnit|first=David|publisher=City Lights Publishers|year=2004|isbn=0872864200|location=San Francisco|pages=4–8}}</ref>
He has supported protests inside the [[United Nations Climate Change conference|United Nations COP Climate Talks]] that criticize the failure of the process to address the climate crisis<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/democracy-now/iced-out-of-global-warmin_b_796125.html|title=Civil Society Groups Protest Exclusion from U.N. Climate Summit, Photojournalist Detained and Beaten|last=Now!|first=Democracy|date=2010-12-15|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-05}}</ref> as well as worked to amplify the voices of North American indigenous leaders participating in the UN forum.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Breaking the Spell: A History of Anarchist Filmmakers, Videotape Guerrillas and Digital Ninjas|last=Robé|first=Chris|publisher=PM Press|year=2017|isbn=978-1-62963-233-9|location=Oakland|pages=280–291}}</ref> Reinsborough is an advocate for the climate movement taking stronger leadership from fossil-fuel impacted communities as a way to accelerate a just transition to a renewable energy future.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3eARBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA249&lpg=PA249&dq=%22patrick+reinsborough%22&source=bl&ots=1Fdoa_qc6m&sig=Li8cjDO-fITBRQW8nads498ylzo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiloKKb5NDLAhUJ32MKHVk8CEM4FBDoAQgrMAM#v=onepage&q=%22patrick%20reinsborough%22&f=false|title=Don't Even Think About It: Why Our Brains Are Wired to Ignore Climate Change|last=Marshall|first=George|date=2014-08-19|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing USA|isbn=9781620401330|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=C SS|title=Which Future?|date=2014-02-18|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CYsNglZqgXM|accessdate=2018-02-05}}</ref> He has been a strong critic of the Trump administration, calling them "neo-fascist" and pawns of “global petrocapitalism”.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/ralphbenko/2017/01/29/the-left-wages-war-on-donald-trump-its-godzilla/|title=The Left Wages War On Donald Trump, Its Godzilla|last=Benko|first=Ralph|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-04-06|language=en}}</ref>
== External links == * [https://www.patrickreinsborough.com Official website] * [https://www.storybasedstrategy.org Center for Story-based Strategy] * [http://beautifultrouble.org Beautiful Trouble]
== References == {{reflist}}

revision.comment: Reverted to revision 849245475 by [[Special:Contributions/Ira Leviton|Ira Leviton]] ([[User talk:Ira Leviton|talk]]). ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
[[File:Tien Ora noot (Racheltjie de Beer).jpg|thumb|Racheltjie de Beer on a ten [[Ora (currency)|Ora]] note]] '''Rachel de Beer''' ({{IPA-nl|raˈχelki də ˈbiər|}}, 1831–1843) (sometimes known by the diminutive form, ''Racheltjie'') is an [[Afrikaner]] [[hero]]ine,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Antonites|first=Alex|date=June 2008|title=Suid-Afrika na dertien jaar (1994 -2007) |journal=Tydskrif vir Geesteswetenskappe|volume=48|issue=2|pages=159, 164|language=Afrikaans|hdl=2263/6057}}</ref> who gave her life in order to save that of her brother, Dirkie de Beer. She was the daughter of George Stephanus de Beer (b. 1794).<ref>Illustrated at the Fireside, Spearhead 2004, {{ISBN|0-86486-558-9}}</ref>
==Story== In the winter months of 1843 Rachel was part of a trek from the [[Orange Free State]] to the south-eastern [[South African Republic|Transvaal]]. During one of their nightly stopovers, the members of the trek realised that a [[calf]] called Frik, much-beloved by their children, was missing.
A search party was formed, in which Rachel and her six-year-old brother also took part. However, during the gathering [[dusk]] Rachel and her brother got separated from the search party and became lost. As the night progressed it got very cold and started [[snow]]ing.
Realizing that their chances of survival were slim, Rachel found an [[anthill]] hollowed out by an [[aardvark]], took off her clothes, put them on her brother and commanded him to get into the hollowed-out anthill. She then lay in front of the opening of the anthill in order to keep out the cold.
The children were found the next morning by the trekking party. Rachel was dead, but her brother had survived.
It is possible that neither of the children existed,<ref name="Nieuwoudt">{{cite news|last=Nieuwoudt |first=Stephanie |title=Racheltjie: ware heldin of versinsel?|newspaper=[[Die Burger]]|date=2002-10-01|language=Afrikaans}}</ref> however. The history of the period is not well documented. To date no undisputed proof has been presented to substantiate any claims regarding Racheltjie de Beer.
Fiction or not, Rachel de Beer is entrenched in the Afrikaner culture, which is evident by the number of streets and schools named after her.
==Genealogical perspective== In the very comprehensive genealogical work “The De Beer Family – Three centuries in South Africa”<ref>Page 72-77, Die De Beer-Familie – Drie Eeue in Suid-Afrika, First edition, June 2000, Dawid W. de Beer & Jaleen de Beer, {{ISBN|0-620-26029-7}}</ref> several pages are devoted to the Rachel de Beer story, looking at all the possibilities from the available genealogical data.
It turns out that there was a De Beer family that fits the names and ages as mentioned in the original story quite closely. However, they lived 60 years later. If the incident happened in 1903 instead of 1843, this family would fit the facts quite nicely. It would also better explain why there is no mention of this story before the early 1900s.
By the third edition of the work<ref>Page 80-85, Die De Beer-Familie – Drie Eeue in Suid-Afrika, Third edition (CD only), March 2005, Dawid W. de Beer & Jaleen de Beer, {{ISBN|0-620-33884-9}}</ref> more information has come to light to also eliminate this last possible scenario. The Rachel de Beer in this instance has been confirmed to have lived well into adulthood.
Based on this research it seems unlikely that the story of Rachel de Beer is factual.
==Historicity debate== In October 2012, two Afrikaans journalists published their findings that the story of Racheltjie de Beer bears many similarities to that of the American heroine [[Hazel Miner]]. They wrote about it in the tabloid ''By'', a weekly supplement of the three Afrikaans newspapers ''Die Burger'', ''Beeld'', and ''Volksblad''.<ref>Was Racheltjie eintlik ’n Amerikaner? http://www.dieburger.com/By/Nuus/Was-Racheltjie-eintlik-n-Amerikaner-20121006</ref> The very first story about Rachel appeared in print only about a month or three after the ''North Dakota Children's Home Finder'' gave Hazel Miner's (true) story the wider publicity that it had deserved. The Afrikaans journalists also posted a more elaborate paper on their findings to the web under the title ''Die laaste rits bewyse: Racheltjie is bloot 'n afspieëling van Hazel Miner (The last series of evidences: Little Rachel is merely a mirror image of Hazel Miner)''.<ref>Racheltjie is bloot 'n afspieëling van Hazel Miner {{cite web |url=http://mysite.mweb.co.za/residents/dugeot/rachel_hazel.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304003241/http://mysite.mweb.co.za/residents/dugeot/rachel_hazel.html |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|1}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Beer, Rachel De}} [[Category:1831 births]] [[Category:1843 deaths]] [[Category:Afrikaner people]] [[Category:White South African people]] [[Category:19th-century South African people]] [[Category:Great Trek]] [[Category:South African people of Dutch descent]]

{{Infobox Ethnic group |group = Roanoke |population = Extinct as a tribe |regions = [[North Carolina]] |region1 = |region2 = |pop1 = |ref1 = |region3 = |religions = [[Tribal religion]] (historical) |languages = Carolina [[Algonquian languages|Algonquian]] (historical) |related = [[Croatan]] [[Secotan]] [[Pamlico]] [[Machapunga]] }} The '''Roanoke''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|r|oʊ|ə|ˌ|n|oʊ|k}}), also spelled '''Roanoac''', were a Carolina [[Algonquian languages|Algonquian]]-speaking people whose territory comprised present-day [[Dare County]], [[Roanoke Island]] and part of the mainland at the time of English exploration and [[colonization]]. They were one of the numerous [[Carolina Algonquian]] tribes, which may have numbered [[Population history of indigenous peoples of the Americas|5,000-10,000]] people in total in eastern North Carolina at the time of English encounter.<ref name="nps-enc">[http://www.nps.gov/fora/forteachers/indian-towns-and-buildings-of-eastern-north-carolina.htm "Indian Towns and Buildings of Eastern North Carolina"], ''Fort Raleigh National Historic Site'', National Park Service, 2008, accessed 24 Apr 2010</ref>
The last known [[tribal chief|chief]] of the Roanoke was [[Wanchese (chief)|Wanchese]], who traveled to England with colonists in 1584. The smaller [[Croatan]] people may have been a branch of the Roanoke or a separate tribe allied with it.<ref name="nps-enc" />
==History== The Roanoke may have had their capital on the western shore of [[Croatan Sound]], at ''Dasamonguepeuk''. This was one of the significant towns noted by the English colonists in the sixteenth century.<ref name="nps-enc" />
Numerous place names were derived from the Roanoke.
==See also== *[[Algonquian languages]] *[[Algonquian peoples]] *[[Croatan]] *[[European colonization of the Americas|European Colonization of the Americas]] *[[Colonial history of the United States]] *[[English colonial empire]] *[[History of North Carolina]] *[[History of the United States]] *[[Pre-Columbian era|Pre-Columbian Era]] *[[Genocide of indigenous peoples]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links==

revision.text:
'''Rudolf Battěk''' (2 November 1924 – 17 March 2013) was a [[Czech Republic|Czech]] [[sociologist]], [[politician]], and political [[dissident]] during [[Czechoslovakia]] Communist era.
==Biography== Battěk co-founded the [[Club of Committed Non-Party Members]] (KAN) in 1968, which promoted human rights.<ref name=pdm>{{cite news|first=|last=|title=Former dissident, post-1989 politician Battěk dies|url=http://praguemonitor.com/2013/03/18/former-dissident-post-1989-politician-batt%C4%9Bk-dies-aged-88|work=[[Prague Daily Monitor]]|publisher=|date=2013-03-18|accessdate=2013-03-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131216190350/http://praguemonitor.com/2013/03/18/former-dissident-post-1989-politician-batt%C4%9Bk-dies-aged-88|archivedate=2013-12-16|df=}}</ref> KAN was banned by the Soviet Union following the [[Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia]] later in 1968.<ref name=pdm/> Battěk was arrested and imprisoned on two occasions for activities against the [[Communist regime in Czechoslovakia]].<ref name=pdm/> He spent ten years imprisoned by Communist authorities during the 1970s and 1980s.<ref name=pdm/>
Battěk was a signatory of [[Charter 77]], which criticized the Communist regime for rejecting [[human rights]].<ref name=pdm/> He also joined the Committee for the Defence of the Unjustly Prosecuted.<ref name=pdm/>
In 1989, Battěk re-entered politics following the [[Velvet Revolution]]. He joined the [[Czech Social Democratic Party]] (ČSSD), but was expelled from the party in June 1990.<ref name=pdm/> Battěk became a member of the Association of Social Democrats after his expulsion from the ČSSD. In 1993, the leadership of the ČSSD reversed its original decision to expel Battěk and invited him to rejoin the ČSSD.<ref name=pdm/> Battěk declined the offer to rejoin the ČSSD, choosing to remain a member of the Association of Social Democrats.<ref name=pdm/> In 1996, Battěk ran as a candidate for the [[Senate of the Parliament of the Czech Republic]] as an independent from ward 8 in Prague, but lost the election.<ref name=pdm/>
In 1997, he was awarded the [[Order of Tomáš Garrigue Masaryk]] by [[President of the Czech Republic]] [[Václav Havel]].<ref name=pdm/>
Rudolf Battěk died on 17 March 2013, at the age of 88.<ref name=pdm/>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox chef | name = Sarma Melngailis | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1972|9|10}} | birth_place = [[Newton, Massachusetts]], USA | death_date = | death_place = | style = [[Raw foodism]] | education = [[University of Pennsylvania]]
[[Wharton School]]
[[French Culinary Institute]] | ratings = | restaurants = {{Unbulleted list | Pure Food and Wine | One Lucky Duck Juice and Takeaway }} | spouse = Anthony Strangis (also known as "Shane Fox") | website = {{URL|oneluckyduck.com}} }} '''Sarma Melngailis''' (born 10 September 1972) is the former owner and co-founder of Pure Food and Wine, a [[raw foodism]] restaurant in [[New York City]],{{cite news|url=http://blogs.villagevoice.com/forkintheroad/archives/2009/12/post_19.php|title=Chatting With Sarma Melngailis of Pure Food and Wine: Raw Food, Criticism From Vegan Purists, and Global Expansion|last=Miller|first=Jenny|date=11 December 2009|work=Fork in the road|publisher=Village Voice|accessdate=16 December 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091214070619/http://blogs.villagevoice.com/forkintheroad/archives/2009/12/post_19.php|archivedate=14 December 2009|df=}} and the founder and CEO of One Lucky Duck.{{cite news|url=http://www.papermag.com/blogs/2009/03/spring_cleaning_with_sarma_mei.php|title=Spring Cleaning With... Sarma Melngailis|last=Frakes|first=Julia|date=30 March 2009|work=Paper Magazine|accessdate=16 December 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100214105036/http://www.papermag.com/blogs/2009/03/spring_cleaning_with_sarma_mei.php|archivedate=14 February 2010|df=}} ==Background== Melngailis was born and raised in [[Newton, Massachusetts]] and attended [[Newton North High School]]. Her early interest in food came from her mother, a professional chef. Her father was a physicist at MIT. MeIngalis, Sarma. ''One Lucky Duck'' http://oneluckyduck.com/pages/about-sarma Accessed June 6, 2016 Melngailis graduated from the [[University of Pennsylvania]] in 1994 with a B.A. in Economics and a B.S. in Economics from the [[Wharton School]]. She moved to New York City, working at [[Bear Stearns]] until 1996, then moving to [[Bain Capital]] in Boston on private equity investment. She returned to New York City in 1998 and joined a high-yield investment fund at CIBC, but soon left to enroll at New York’s [[French Culinary Institute]] from which she graduated in 1999. ==Business== Together with her then boyfriend chef, author and speaker [[Matthew Kenney]],{{cite web|last1=Felsenthal|first1=Julia|title=Chef Matthew Kenney on the Plant-Based Revolution Coming Soon to a City Near You|url=http://www.vogue.com/13391662/chef-matthew-kenney-plant-based-food-revolution/|website=vogue.com|publisher=Vogue|accessdate=13 May 2016|date=25 January 2016|quote=In 2004 Matthew Kenney and his then girlfriend, Sarma Melngailis, opened Pure Food and Wine...}}{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C05E6D8163FF931A25753C1A9639C8B63|title=Owner and Manager In Dispute With Chef|last=Fabricant|first=Florence|date=12 October 2005|work=New York Times|accessdate=16 December 2009}} she opened Commissary in 2001, but it closed in March 2003, after which she consulted for [[Jeffrey Chodorow|Jeffrey Chodorow's]] China Grill Management. With Chodorow and Kenney, Melngailis opened Pure Food and Wine in June 2004 as New York City’s first upscale [[raw food]] restaurant.{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m3190/is_32_38/ai_n6153892/|title=Sarma Melngailis: ex-financier uses raw talent in the kitchen|last=Duecy|first=Erica|date=9 August 2004|work=Nation's Restaurant News|accessdate=16 December 2009}}{{cite web|last1=Fabricant|first1=Florence|title=Owner and Manager in Dispute With Chef|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/12/dining/owner-and-manager-in-dispute-with-chef.html|website=nytimes.com|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=21 May 2016|language=English|date=12 October 2005}}{{cite web|url=http://observer.com/2010/01/a-rough-time-in-smoothie-world-rawfood-queen-scuffles-with-chelsea-market/|title=A Rough Time in Smoothie World: Raw-Food Queen Scuffles With Chelsea Market|author=Meredith Bryan|date=13 January 2010|work=Observer|accessdate=14 May 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/restaurants/chatting-with-sarma-melngailis-of-pure-food-and-wine-raw-food-criticism-from-vegan-purists-and-global-expansion-6515322|title=Chatting With Sarma Melngailis of Pure Food and Wine: Raw Food, Criticism From Vegan Purists, and Global Expansion|author=Jenny Miller|date=11 December 2009|work=Village Voice|accessdate=14 May 2016}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/16/dining/food-stuff-off-the-menu.html|title=Food Stuff; Off the Menu|last=Fabricant|first=Florence|date=16 June 2004|work=New York Times|accessdate=16 December 2009}} Located in Manhattan's [[Gramercy Park]] neighborhood, the restaurant was listed twice in New York magazine’s “Top 100 Restaurants”{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/listings/restaurant/pure-food-and-wine/|title=Pure Food and Wine|work=NYMag.com|accessdate=14 May 2016}} and five years in a row in Forbes magazine’s list of “All Star New York Eateries."{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2008/1222/019b.html|title=The Forbes 2008 All-Star Eateries in New York: Three Stars|author=Steve Forbes|date=4 December 2008|work=Forbes|accessdate=14 May 2016}} One Lucky Duck Juice and Takeaway[http://stanford.wellsphere.com/raw-food-article/nyc-pure-food-and-wine-pt1-one-lucky-duck-juice-and-takeaway/750348 One Lucky Duck Takeaway review] is the name of the takeaway retail store attached to the restaurant, Pure Food and Wine. OneLuckyDuck.com, launched in 2005, is an online store for snacks prepared and packaged from her restaurant as well as ingredients, skincare, supplements, books, apparel, and home products, all related to raw and organic living. A second One Lucky Duck location was open in New York City's Chelsea Market from December 2009 through January 2015.{{cite news|url=http://dinersjournal.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/10/29/off-the-menu-new-kiosks-at-chelsea-market/?scp=1&sq=%22one%20lucky%20duck%22&st=cse|title=Off the Menu: New Kiosks at Chelsea Market|author=Florence Fabricant|publisher=The New York Times|date=29 October 2009|accessdate=14 May 2016}} In 2014, One Lucky Duck Juice and Takeaway's first location outside of New York City opened in San Antonio, Texas.{{cite web|title=NEW JUICE BAR IN… TEXAS!|url=http://ducknews.oneluckyduck.com/2013/09/26/one-lucky-duck-san-antonio/|website=ducknews.oneluckyduck.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150430210633/http://ducknews.oneluckyduck.com/2013/09/26/one-lucky-duck-san-antonio/|archivedate=2015-04-30|df=}} ===Controversy=== In January 2015, Pure Food and Wine and One Lucky Duck staff walked out en masse due to Melngailis' failure to pay employees a month's worth of owed wages.{{cite news|url=http://ny.eater.com/2015/1/13/7539521/pure-food-wine-is-dark-tonight-as-staff-walks-out-over-unpaid-wages|title=Union Square's Pure Food & Wine Currently Closed, After Staff Walks Out En Masse|last= Ferst|first= Devra|date=13 January 2015|work=Eater}} This was the second time in a year a month's worth of wages had been withheld from employees, the first happening in July 2014.{{cite news|url=http://gothamist.com/2015/01/13/pure_food_and_wine_walkout.php|title=Pure Food And Wine Employees Walk Out Over Unpaid Wages|last=Casey|first=Nell|date=13 January 2015|work=Gothamist|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150211120648/http://gothamist.com/2015/01/13/pure_food_and_wine_walkout.php|archivedate=11 February 2015|df=}} On February 8, 2015 Melngailis addressed the walkout and closure in a blog post.{{cite news|url=http://sarmaraw.oneluckyduck.com/2015/02/happened/|title=WHAT HAPPENED?|last=Melingailis|first=Sarma|date=8 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209082050/http://sarmaraw.oneluckyduck.com/2015/02/happened/|archivedate=9 February 2015|df=}} She apologized for the incident, but the blog post was subsequently removed. In an interview with Well+Good, Melngalis said that the delayed wages were due to slim margins caused by debts and expensive ingredients, and that she had also previously missed her own rent payments.{{cite news|url=http://wellandgood.com/2015/02/10/exclusive-sarma-melngailis-strike-at-pure-food-and-wine/|title=Exclusive: Sarma Melngailis opens up about what’s going on at Pure Food and Wine|last=Held|first=Lisa Elaine|work=Well+Good|date=February 10, 2015|accessdate=March 25, 2015}} During the ordeal, Melingailis provided employees a different explanation, blaming the situation on changing banks.{{cite news|last1=Preston|first1=Marguerite|title=What's Going On at Pure Food & Wine, Where Staff Remains Unpaid and Owner Is MIA|url=http://ny.eater.com/2015/1/16/7556849/whats-going-on-at-pure-food-wine-where-staff-remains-unpaid-and-owner|publisher=Eater NY|date=Jan 16, 2015}} In April 2015, Pure Food and Wine, One Lucky Duck, and OneLuckyDuck.com reopened.{{cite web|title=WE’RE BACK: ONE LUCKY DUCK IS OPEN!|url=http://ducknews.oneluckyduck.com/2015/05/04/re-open/|website=ducknews.oneluckyduck.com|publisher=One Lucky Duck|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150605025220/http://ducknews.oneluckyduck.com/2015/05/04/re-open/|archivedate=2015-06-05|df=}} A majority of staff did not return to the restaurant after its reopening.{{cite news|last1=Tishgart|first1=Sierra|title=How a Prominent Restaurant Owner Is Bouncing Back After a Public Staff Exodus|url=http://www.grubstreet.com/2015/04/pure-food-wine-returns.html|publisher=Grub Street|date=April 30, 2015}} Again in July 2015, the staff of Pure Food and Wine as well as One Lucky Duck walked out due to unpaid wages. The Restaurant has been permanently shut down. ====Arrest==== On May 12, 2016, it was reported that Sarma and her husband Anthony Strangis (also known as "Shane Fox"){{cite web|title=Fugitive restaurateur who championed raw food caught, charged|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/fugitive-restaurateur-who-championed-raw-food-caught-charged/|website=cbsnews.com|publisher=CBS News Crimesider|accessdate=13 May 2016|date=13 May 2016}} were arrested in [[Sevierville, Tennessee]], after ordering a pizza from Domino's Pizza.{{cite web|author1=Emily Saul|author2=Carlos Greer|author3=Beckie Strum|title=Vegan restaurateur ordered Dominos before $2M bust|url=https://nypost.com/2016/05/13/vegan-restraunteur-was-scarfing-down-pizza-before-2m-bust/|website=nypost.com|publisher=New York Post|accessdate=14 May 2016}}{{cite news|title=Latvian American celebrity vegan betrayed by cheesy pizza|url=http://www.lsm.lv/en/article/societ/society/latvian-american-celebrity-vegan-betrayed-by-cheesy-pizza.a182982/|accessdate=16 May 2016|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting of Latvia]]|date=16 May 2016}} It has been reported that "(I)n addition to the fugitive from justice warrants, Strangis was wanted for grand larceny, scheme to defraud and violation of labor law. Melngailas was wanted for grand larceny, criminal tax fraud, scheme to defraud and violation of labor law."{{cite web|title=2 New York fugitives arrested in Sevierville|url=http://wate.com/2016/05/11/2-new-york-fugitives-arrested-in-sevierville|website=wate.com|publisher=[[WATE-TV|WATE 6]]|accessdate=14 May 2016|date=11 May 2016}}{{cite web|title=Owner of Vegan Food Business and her Husband Indicted for Allegedly Stealing from Employees, Defrauding Investors, not Paying Taxes|url=http://www.brooklynda.org/2016/05/12/owner-of-vegan-food-business-and-her-husband-indicted-for-allegedly-stealing-from-employees-defrauding-investors-not-paying-taxes/|website=brooklynda.org|publisher=The Brooklyn District Attorney's Office|accessdate=13 May 2016|date=12 May 2016}} On December 19, 2016, prosecutors offered Melngailis a plea deal in which she would agree to serve one to three years in prison.{{cite news |last1=Avila |first1=Theresa |title=Prosecutors Offer Plea Deal to the Vegan Restaurateur Facing Grand-Larceny Charges |url=http://nymag.com/thecut/2016/12/prosecutors-offer-plea-deal-to-sarma-melngailis-of-pure-food.html |accessdate=27 February 2017 |publisher=New York Magazine |date=December 20, 2016 }}{{cite news |last1=DeGregory|first1=Priscilla |title='Vegan Bernie Madoff' gets plea deal offer |url=https://nypost.com/2016/12/19/vegan-bernie-madoff-gets-plea-deal-offer/ |accessdate=27 February 2017 |publisher=The New York Post |date=December 19, 2016 }} Melngailis' attorneys were reported by ''Vanity Fair'' to be planning a "[[coercive control]]" defence.{{cite news|title=Why Sarma Melngailis, the “Vegan Fugitive,” Is Using a “Gaslighting” Defense|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/style/2017/03/sarma-melngailis-vegan-fugitive-defense|work=Vanity Fair|last=Salkin|first=Allen|date=March 2, 2017|accessdate=April 13, 2017}} ==Bibliography== *''Raw Food/Real World'' (2005){{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/lifestyle/2005/08/24/2005-08-24_book_review__what_s_cooking_.html|title=What's cooking? Nothing|last=Black|first=Rosemary|date=24 August 2005|work=New York Daily News|accessdate=16 December 2009}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *''Living Raw Food'' (2009) ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20150318073747/http://sarmaraw.oneluckyduck.com/ Archived blog posts by Sarma] *[http://oneluckyduck.com/sarma/ Sarma Raw (Blog)] *[http://www.oneluckyduck.com One Lucky Duck site] *[http://www.harpercollins.com/author/microsite/About.aspx?authorid=29315 Sarma Melngailis Listing from HarperCollins Publishers] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Melngailis, Sarma}} [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:American restaurateurs]] [[Category:Women restaurateurs]] [[Category:American people of Latvian descent]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Newton, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Businesspeople from New York City]] [[Category:Raw foodists]] [[Category:American company founders]] [[Category:Women company founders]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2017}} '''Sonya Haddad''' (November 9, 1936 – June 15, 2004) was a [[libretto]] translator and [[surtitles|surtitler]] for the [[Metropolitan Opera]] in New York. == Life and career == Haddad was born in [[Canton, Ohio]], on November 9, 1936, and grew up in [[Akron]]. She graduated from the [[Eastman School of Music]] at the [[University of Rochester]] in 1958. She subsequently worked in the classical music division of [[Columbia Records]], and at ''[[The New York Times]]''{{'}} radio station [[WQXR-FM|WQXR]]. From 1960 until the early 1970s she worked at the [[Festival of Two Worlds]] in [[Spoleto]], Italy. During that time, she also lived part-time in Rome where she worked as an interpreter. She acted as courier with the kidnappers of [[John Paul Getty III]] in 1973. {{External media|image1=[https://www.operanews.com/_uploaded/image/article/obits.jpg Sonya Haddad]}} Haddad was fluent in German, Italian and French. She began working at the Metropolitan Opera in 1994. was referred to in her obituary in ''[[The New York Times]]'' as "one of the country's leading practitioners of her art".{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/23/us/sonya-haddad-67-translator-for-met-opera-s-titling-system.html|title=Sonya Haddad, 67, Translator For Met Opera's Titling System|last=Zinoman|first=Jason|authorlink=Jason Zinoman|date=June 23, 2004|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=August 28, 2017}} She wrote surtitles or subtitles for the [[Washington National Opera]], [[La Scala]] in Milan, and the [[Public Broadcasting Service]]'s series ''[[Great Performances]]''. She joined the editorial staff of ''[[Opera News]]'' in 1998,[https://www.operanews.com/Opera_News_Magazine/2004/9/Departments/Obituaries.html "Obituaries – Sonya Haddad" (with picture)] by Brian Kellow, ''[[Opera News]]'', vol. 69, no. 3, September 2004 and was a research associate for the magazine until her death in 2004.{{Cite web|url=https://www.operanews.com/Opera_News_Magazine/2012/6/Departments/Viewpoint__Summer_Memories.html|title=Viewpoint: Summer Memories|work=[[Opera News]]|access-date=August 28, 2017}} At the time of her death, she lived in [[The Bronx]]. [[Brian Kellow]] said of her in an obituary in ''Opera News'' that "As a titlist, her standards were high: she took pains to avoid the cute, the coy, the anachronistic; her titles were as precise and elegant and clearly thought out as her own prose." William Romano, in an article partly based around documentation supplied by Haddad, said of her work that "by extending the text's exposure in live performance by a fraction of a second, the titleist imperceptibly adjusts the viewer's engagement with the words'.{{Cite journal|last=Romano|first=William|date=Summer 2010|title=Reading at the Opera|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/394137|journal=University of Toronto Quarterly|volume=79|pages=3|via=[[Project MUSE]]}} {{subscription}} He goes on to argue that
Titling challenges titleists and the houses that employ them not only to translate but to make the best case for awkward and weak librettos. The brief, repetitious texts and credulity-straining plots of the bel canto repertory, with their attenuated melodic lines and spectacular runs, can pose more challenges to a titleist than do the complex texts of an opera by Strauss or Wagner. Titling, like any aspect of performance, is a dynamic technical skill, and a titleist may return to an opera in subsequent seasons, adjusting and refining both word choice and the technical aspects of delivery. However the titleist resolves these questions, the resulting version becomes the audience's live-time reading matter.
Operas for which Haddad did the translation and surtitling in the course of her career include: [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky|Tchaikovsky]]'s ''[[The Queen of Spades (opera)|The Queen of Spades]]'' in 1995; Prokofiev's ''[[War and Peace (opera)|War and Peace]]''; [[Giuseppe Verdi|Verdi]]'s ''[[Falstaff (opera)|Falstaff]]''{{Cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/460328/Falstaff/|title=TCM synopsis of ''Falstaff''|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} and ''[[I vespri siciliani]]'';{{Cite web|url=https://searchworks.stanford.edu/view/4771294|title=''I Vespri siciliani'' [videorecording] : opera in five acts|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} [[Richard Strauss]]'s ''[[Capriccio (opera)|Capriccio]]'';{{Cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-08-07/entertainment/ca-4642_1_strauss-final-opera|title=TV Review : A Welcome Production of Strauss' Final Opera|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} [[Gioachino Rossini|Rossini]]'s ''[[La donna del lago]]'';{{Cite web|url=https://searchworks.stanford.edu/view/4771782|title=''La donna del lago'' [videorecording] : opera in two acts|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]]'s ''[[Così fan tutte]]'' and ''[[Don Giovanni]]''; [[Giovanni Battista Pergolesi|Pergolesi]]'s ''[[Lo frate 'nnamorato]]'' and [[Conrad Susa]]'s ''[[The Dangerous Liaisons]]''. == References == {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Haddad, Sonya}} [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:2004 deaths]] [[Category:People from Canton, Ohio]] [[Category:Eastman School of Music alumni]] [[Category:American subtitlers]] [[Category:American translators]] [[Category:Translators to English]] [[Category:Literary translators]] [[Category:Metropolitan Opera people]] [[Category:20th-century translators]] [[Category:21st-century translators]] [[Category:People from Akron, Ohio]]

{{other uses2|Steak knife}} "'''Stakeknife'''" is the code name of a high-level [[Espionage|spy]] who successfully infiltrated the [[Provisional Irish Republican Army]] (IRA) while working for the top secret [[Force Research Unit]] (FRU) of the [[British Army]].<ref>{{Cite news |last=|first=|title=Focus: Scappaticci's past is secret no more |pages=|publisher=[[The Times]] |date=18 May 2003 |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2091-683795,00.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070311005439/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2091-683795,00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=11 March 2007 |accessdate=2007-02-11|location=London}}</ref><ref name="Grauniad, 2003" /> Reports claim that Stakeknife worked for British intelligence for 25 years.<ref name="Grauniad, 2003">{{Cite news |last=Cowan |first=Rosie |title=He did the IRA's dirty work for 25 years - and was paid £80,000 a year by the government |pages=|publisher=[[The Guardian]] |date=12 May 2003 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk_news/story/0,,953842,00.html |accessdate=2007-02-11 |location=London}}</ref> Stakeknife has been accused of being a [[double agent]] who oversaw the murders of informers within the paramilitary organisation while working for the British.<ref name="theguardian300118">{{cite news |last1=McDonald |first1=Henry |last2=Cobain |first2=Ian |title=IRA informer ‘Stakeknife’ arrested in murder investigation |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/jan/30/ira-informer-stakeknife-arrested-in-investigation |work=The Guardian |date=30 January 2018 |language=en}}</ref> British officials launched Operation Kenova to investigate these claims of state involvement in kidnap, torture and murder of more than 50 individuals, leading to the arrest of [[Freddie Scappaticci]] in January 2018 on accusations that he is Stakeknife. Scappaticci has denied that he is the notorious spy.<ref name="telegraph30912018">{{cite news |last1=Farmer |first1=Ben |title=Army spy 'Stakeknife' who was head of IRA's internal security is arrested in investigation over murders |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/01/30/army-spy-stakeknife-head-iras-internal-security-arrested-investigation/ |accessdate=9 July 2018 |work=The Telegraph |date=30 January 2018}}</ref>
==Activity== "Stakeknife" had his own dedicated handlers and agents, and it was suggested that he was important enough that [[MI5]] set up an office dedicated solely to him. Rumours suggested that he was being paid at least £80,000 a year and had a bank account in [[Gibraltar]].<ref name="theguardian2003">{{cite news |last1=Cowan |first1=Rosie |title=He did the IRA's dirty work for 25 years - and was paid £80,000 a year by the government |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2003/may/12/northernireland.northernireland1 |accessdate=9 July 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=12 May 2003 |language=en}}</ref>
Serious allegations have emerged to the effect that the [[British government]] allowed up to 40 people to be killed via the IRA's [[Internal Security Unit]] or "Nutting Squad" to protect his cover.<ref>{{Cite news |last=|first=|title=Murder fear after naming of IRA spy |pages=|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |date=12 May 2003 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1429810/Murder-fear-after-naming-of-IRA-spy.html |accessdate=2007-02-11|location=London}}</ref>
==Purported exposure== In 1987, [[Sam McCrory (loyalist)|Sam McCrory]], an [[Ulster Defence Association]]/"Ulster Freedom Fighters" member, killed the 66-year-old [[Francisco Notarantonio]] at his home in [[Springfield Road, Belfast|Ballymurphy]] in West Belfast.<ref>Wood, Ian S. ''Crimes of Loyalty: A History of the UDA''. Edinburgh University Press, 2006. p.125</ref> The UDA/UFF had discovered that a senior IRA member was working for the FRU. It has been alleged that FRU agent [[Brian Nelson (Northern Irish loyalist)|Brian Nelson]] gave Notarantonio's name to the UDA/UFF to protect the identity of the real spy.
On 11 May 2003, several newspapers named [[Freddie Scappaticci]] as Stakeknife. Scappaticci, born in Belfast to Italian parents, denied the claims and launched an unsuccessful legal action to have the British government state he was not their agent.<ref name="theguardian2003"/><ref>{{Cite news |last=Oliver |first=Ted |title='Stakeknife' loses bid to quash spy claim |pages=|publisher=The Guardian |date=19 August 2003 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/Northern_Ireland/Story/0,,1021579,00.html |accessdate=2007-02-11|location=London}}</ref> He later left Northern Ireland and was rumoured to be living in [[Cassino, Italy|Cassino]], Italy. There were also reported sightings in [[Tenerife]].<ref>{{Cite news|last=Harkin|first=Greg|title=British spy hunted by IRA flees refuge|pages=|publisher=[[The Independent]]|date=9 April 2006|url=http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/ulster/article356668.ece|accessdate=2007-02-11|location=London|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070314015841/http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/ulster/article356668.ece|archivedate=14 March 2007 }}</ref>
A report in a February 2007 edition of the ''[[Belfast News Letter]]'' reported that a cassette recording allegedly of Scappaticci talking about the number of murders he was involved in via the "Nutting Squad", as well as his work as an Army agent, had been lodged with the [[Police Service of Northern Ireland|PSNI]] in 2004 and subsequently passed to the [[Stevens Inquiries|Stevens Inquiry]] in 2005.<ref>{{Cite news |last=|first=|title=Stakeknife tape emerges after News Letter probe |pages=|publisher=Belfast Today |date=5 February 2007 |url=http://www.belfasttoday.net/ViewArticle2.aspx?SectionID=3425&ArticleID=2023120 |accessdate=2007-02-11 }} </ref>
The former British Intelligence agent who worked in the FRU known as "[[Martin Ingram]]" has written a book titled ''Stakeknife'' since the original allegations came to light in which it says Scappaticci was the agent in question.
In October 2015 it was announced that Scappaticci was to be investigated by the Police Service of Northern Ireland over at least 24 murders.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Stakeknife: Army's most high ranking agent within the IRA to be quizzed about 24 murders |publisher=BBC News |date=21 October 2015 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-34594175 |accessdate=2015-10-21 }}</ref> In June 2016 it was announced that this investigation would be carried out by [[Bedfordshire Police]] and would examine the possible involvement of members of the RUC, Army and MI5 in murders carried out by the IRA, and their knowledge of them through the information supplied via Stakeknife.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Stakeknife: Actions of IRA members, agents, Army and police to be examined |newspaper=[[BBC News Online]] |date=10 June 2016 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-36494590}}</ref> Scappaticci was arrested in connection with Operation Kenova in January 2018.<ref name="telegraph30912018"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Matthew Teague, (April 2006) "[https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2006/04/double-blind/304710/ Double Blind: The untold story of how British intelligence infiltrated and undermined the IRA]." ''[[The Atlantic]]'' * Greg Harkin and Martin Ingram (2004), ''Stakeknife: Britain's secret agents in Ireland'', O'Brien Press * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060508042652/http://www.birw.org/Stakeknife.html British Irish Rights Watch Report]
==External links== *[http://www.opkenova.co.uk/ Operation Kenova]

{{Infobox person |name = Winarti Partaningrat |image = [[File:Winarti Partaningrat.jpg|100px|Winarti Partaningrat]] |image_size = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth-date|September 21, 1922}} |birth_place = [[Java]], [[Indonesia]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1978|05|08|1922|9|21}} |death_place = [[Java]], [[Indonesia]] |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = Indonesian |other_names = |known_for = |education = [[Columbia University]] |occupation = [[librarian]], government official |home_town = }}
'''Winarti Partaningrat''' (September 21, 1922 – May 8, 1978) was an early contributor to Indonesian librarianship, particularly the establishment of special libraries among government agencies.
==Education and government career== After receiving a medical degree in Indonesia, Partaningrat attended [[Columbia University]] where she received a Master’s degree in [[library science]] in 1958. From 1946 to 1951, she worked at the Foreign Broadcasting of [[Radio Republik Indonesia]], followed by seven years with the [[Voice of America]] for [[United Nations Radio]].<ref name="Encyclopedia Library Services">{{cite book|title=World Encyclopedia of Library and Information Services|year=1986|publisher=American Library Association|isbn=0-8389-0427-0|pages=640–641}}</ref> She served as the Head of the Bureau of Documentation for the Council of Sciences of Indonesia and the [[Indonesian Institute of Sciences]].<ref name="Encyclopedia Library Services" />
===National Network System of Library Documentation and Information Systems=== Partaningrat was a leader in the creation of a special library networking system to allow information sharing among government departments. The organization also laid the foundations of library science within the fields of science, technology, biology, agriculture, medicine and humanities. By connecting these specialized libraries and implementing standardized practices, special libraries became pivotal in providing technical function and services within Indonesia.<ref>{{cite book|last=Widharto|title=Libraries and Librarians in Indonesia in the Information Age: Challenges and Risks|publisher=University of the Philippine Institute of Library and Information Science|location=Indonesia|url=http://eprints.rclis.org/11274/1/Paper-widharto_4_CONSAL.pdf}}</ref>
==Selected publications== *1961 ''Scientific Information Facilities in Indonesia'' *1966 ''Characteristics and History of Indonesian Scientific Periodicals'' *1978 ''Masterlist of Southeast Asian Microforms''
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> | name = Zade Dirani | image = | alt = | caption = | image_size = | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_date = {{Birth date|1980|02|01}} | death_date = | origin = Amman, Jordan | instrument = Piano | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]] | occupation = Pianist, Composer | years_active = | label = ZD Records distributed by EMI | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|http://www.zade.com/}} | current_members = | past_members = }}
'''Zade Dirani''' (Arabic: زيد ديراني, born in 1980), is a Jordanian pianist and composer and UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador for the Middle East and North Africa, whose genre blending songs are inspired by Arabic, Latin, pop, and classical music. He has performed before thousands around the world including Queen Elizabeth, Dalai Lama, Nelson Mandela, amongst others.<ref name="InsideTheBeltway">{{Cite web|url= http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2005/may/26/20050526-111738-4328r/?page=2 |title= Inside The Beltway |publisher=washingtontimes.com |accessdate=2010-01-07 }}</ref>
==Work== {{Advert|date=October 2017}} He has released four CDs, which reflect his studies of each culture while attending the [[National Music Conservatory]] in [[Amman]] and the [[Berklee College of Music]] in Boston. Audiences throughout the Middle East, Europe, and the United States have attended his performances held in various places. His albums have reached #3 on the US [[Billboard chart]] and is #1 on the Jordan charts. The CD for Zade’s latest epic project: One Night in Jordan debuted on Billboard at #2 on the New Age Chart, #5 on the Classical Crossover Chart, and #11 on the Overall Classical Chart. Zade’s accompanying DVD also debuted on Billboard’s Top DVD/Music Video Charts at #18. Zade has toured extensively throughout the U.S and other parts of the world. His wild popularity in Jordan has helped his albums consistently reach No. 1 on the Jordanian album charts.
Zade has been officially endorsed by [[YAMAHA]] pianos thus joining the very select artist roster of YAMAHA artists, playing and representing the brand's piano exclusively where ever he plays.
===Roads To You: Celebration of One World=== In 2006, Zade launched an ambitious project entitled "Roads to You, celebration of One World" in Washington, DC under the patronage of Queen Noor of Jordan.
Titled “Roads to You : Celebration of One World,” Zade lead 40 musicians from 18 countries, in a project that showcased participants from war-torn regions coming together and working in an atmosphere of trust and team spirit. Musicians didn't only perform, but shared their talent and heritage with fellow tour members; participate in more than 100 cultural presentations at educational institutions and community/ civic functions in each city; with their host families and friends; and with their own families at home upon their return. Proceeds will support local charities and causes.
The concert tour featured compositions from Zade’s three recordings which include his latest CD, “Beautiful World” released May 2, inspired by his Middle Eastern heritage. His second CD, "Roads to You", was released in June 2004 in the United States featuring Arabic and Latin influences performed by the City of Prague Philharmonic Orchestra and Choir. One of the cuts from the CD, titled “Kingdom of Peace,” was featured at the 2006 Winter Olympics as the Japanese Female Figure Skating Team competed to this song. That song, and the “Roads To You” CD is the collective effort of more than one hundred musicians from different parts of the world, and was recorded in Miami, Beirut, Prague, and Los Angeles. “Roads to You”, remained on the Billboard Charts more than 20 weeks. His debut CD, self-titled Zade, was released in April 2003, and featured a host of guest musicians from the Middle East and the United States including Charlie Bisharat on Violin, Chris Chaney on Bass (Alanis Morrissette, Jane’s Addiction), Gabriel Gordon on Electric Guitar (Natalie Merchant), and Imane Houmsey on Kanoon (Fairouz, Julia Butros). The album remained on the Billboard Charts for 13 weeks.[2] The CD was supported with performances worldwide, and an extensive “house concert tour” in the U.S.
===One Night In Jordan: A Concert for Peace=== Filmed at one of the oldest [[Roman amphitheater|Roman Amphitheaters]] in the world in Amman, Jordan, One Night In Jordan: A Concert For Peace is a concert performance from Zade. Accompanied by musicians from over 40 nations, including London’s Royal Philharmonic Orchestra, and the London Voices. The album was released on February 9, 2010 by ZD Records and distributed by EMI. The concert DVD was released on March 9, 2010 by ZD Records and distributed by EMI. The concert was aired on PBS stations in 2010 and 2011.
===Zade Foundation for International Peace and Understanding=== To continue cross-cultural understanding through the arts, Zade has launched [[The Zade Foundation]] for International Peace and Understanding aimed at helping young musicians share with the world a deeper understanding of their cultures by offering them a unique opportunity to expand their roles from musicians to proactive peace builders and future community leaders.
===Performances for public figures=== Zade was invited by King Abdullah and [[Queen Rania of Jordan]] to join them on the official state visit to the United Kingdom where he performed before Queen Elizabeth and the British royal family in London. In May 2005, Zade performed at the Library of Congress in Washington DC in celebration of Jordan's National Day by invitation from the Jordanian Ambassador to the United States. He also was invited to perform at the World Economic Forum Extraordinaire 2003 in Jordan. Zade has graced the stage at a tribute to President Nelson Mandela organized by the United Nations Foundation and the Mosaic Foundation in Washington, DC. Other distinctive appearances include "Exploring Jordan" held at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History in Washington, DC.
==Awards== In October 2004, Zade was awarded the American Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee's Distinguished Achievements Award for his work that promotes global understanding through the arts. He has also received The Jordanian Ministry of Education Award for the Arts and The Arab-American Music, Art, and Literature (AMAL) Award.
